long_desc.thetext: This is more of a catch-all or meta bug, and serves mainly to have a bug to link relevant commits to whenever I find a tweak I can apply, in the ongoing search for speed gain. For any concrete issues, please open separate bugs.

Commited a patch that would make TreeLoader.getTree cache trees to memory, for later re-use in the same run, to reduce disk cache I/O. On my Windows box this seemed to have an 25%-30% impact on run time with empty cache. It should only slightly improve run time on a filled cache. In both cases, memory consumption goes up in the range of 12x.
With r20582.

Un-did the previous patch, as newer measurements do not confirm the initial ones. "time" run time on my linux box for Playground actually shows worse run times than without the optimization (the reason for which is unclear to me):
source vesion (real|user) | build version (real|user) w/ patch : 5m52 | 4m28 | 11m30 | 8m40 | w/o patch: 4m36 | 3m33 | 9m16 | 7m0

Removed the first call to 'computeClassList' in Generator.py, before entering the loop over the variant sets. The affected jobs are adapted, by either let actions work on native class lists obtained by the library scan (fix, lint, translation, ...), or delaying real dependency analysis until it is absolutely necessary (api). The most visible impact is on resource copying, which is now done *per variant*. I think copying files around, even multiple times, is still faster than calculating additional dependencies.
With r21601
